summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details Epstein's incarceration history, mental health assessments, events leading to his death, and identifies numerous procedural failures and inconsistencies in his supervision and documentation.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in pretrial detention at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

The reconstruction report identifies numerous systemic failures, including inaccurate inmate cell assignments in SENTRY, failure to complete required 30-minute rounds, and improper documentation of suicide watch and psychological observation logs.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck in an incident initially reported as self-mutilation; he claimed his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione tried to kill him, but an investigation was inconclusive.
Epstein was single-celled on the night of his death because his cellmate, Efrain Reyes, did not return from court, contrary to recommendations that inmates with his risk profile be double-celled.

The report notes that on August 9, 2019, the day before his death, approximately 2,000 pages of court documents containing graphic allegations were unsealed, potentially eroding his status and implicating associates.
